description: Concerning workplace violence in health care settings.

original.text:
H-0373.1
HOUSE BILL 1162
State of Washington
69th Legislature
2025 Regular Session
ByRepresentatives Leavitt, Schmidt, Berry, Ryu, Macri, Bronoske, Pollet, Nance, Timmons, Ormsby, and Hill
Prefiled 01/06/25.Read first time 01/13/25.Referred to Committee on Labor & Workplace Standards.
AN ACT Relating to preventing workplace violence in health care settings; amending RCW 49.19.020; and adding a new section to chapter 49.19 RCW.
BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON:
Sec. 1. RCW 49.19.020 and 2019 c 430 s 2 are each amended to read as follows:
(1) ((Every three years, each))(a) Each health care setting shall develop and implement a workplace violence prevention plan ((to prevent and protect))for the purposes of preventing violence and protecting employees from violence ((at))in the setting.
(b) In a health care setting with a safety committee established pursuant to RCW 49.17.050 and related rules, or workplace violence committee that is comprised of employee-elected and employer-selected members where the number of employee-elected members equal or exceed the number of employer-selected members, ((that))the committee shall develop, implement, and monitor progress on the workplace violence prevention plan.
(2) The workplace violence prevention plan ((developed under subsection (1) of this section shall))must outline strategies aimed at addressing security considerations and factors that may contribute to or prevent the risk of violence, including but not limited to the following:
(a) The physical attributes of the health care setting, including security systems, alarms, emergency response, and security personnel available;
(b) Staffing, including staffing patterns, patient classifications, and procedures to mitigate employees time spent alone working in areas at high risk for workplace violence;
(c) Job design, equipment, and facilities;
(d) First aid and emergency procedures;
(e) The reporting of violent acts;
(f) Employee education and training requirements and implementation strategy;
(g) Security risks associated with specific units, areas of the facility with uncontrolled access, late night or early morning shifts, and employee security in areas surrounding the facility such as employee parking areas; and
(h) Processes and expected interventions to provide assistance to an employee directly affected by a violent act.
(((2) [(3)] Each health care setting shall annually review the frequency of incidents of workplace violence including identification of the causes for and consequences of, violent acts at the setting and any emerging issues that contribute to workplace violence. The health care setting shall adjust the plan developed under subsection (1) of this section as necessary based on this annual review.))
(3) (([(4)])) In developing ((the plan required by subsection (1) of this section))and updating the workplace violence prevention plan, the health care setting shall consider ((any)):
(a) Any guidelines on violence in the workplace or in health care settings issued by the department of health, the department of social and health services, the department of labor and industries, the federal occupational safety and health administration, medicare, and health care setting accrediting organizations; and
(b) The findings and recommendations in the reports required by section 2(2) of this act.
(4) The health care setting or, if applicable, the committee under subsection (1) of this section must conduct a comprehensive review and update of the workplace violence prevention plan at least once per calendar year.
NEW SECTION.  Sec. 2. A new section is added to chapter 49.19 RCW to read as follows:
(1) Every health care setting must conduct a timely investigation of every workplace violence incident.
(2) In each investigation required by this section, the health care setting must review the incident for purposes of identifying factors contributing to or causing workplace violence, including but not limited to an assessment of:
(a) The details of the incident, such as the date, time, location, and nature of the conduct and harm;
(b) The details of any response and related remediation to prevent future incidents; and
(c) If applicable, a comparison of the actual staffing levels to the planned staffing levels at the time of incident.
(3) The health care setting must submit a report to the committee identified under RCW 49.19.020(1)(b) at least quarterly, unless the health care setting is a critical access hospital under 42 U.S.C. Sec. 1395i-4, in which case it must submit a report at least twice per year, with the following:
(a) A summary of the data required by RCW 49.19.040 and the findings of investigations required by subsection (1) of this section during the relevant time period, with any personal information deidentified in compliance with the federal health insurance portability and accountability act of 1996;
(b) A summary and analysis of any systemic and common causes of the workplace violence incidents; and
(c) Recommendations for modifying the plan under RCW 49.19.020 and other practices in order to prevent future incidents of workplace violence.
--- END ---

summary.text:
Purpose

The purpose of House Bill 1162 is to enhance safety and prevent workplace violence in health care settings. The bill amends existing regulations to require more robust violence prevention plans that specifically address factors contributing to workplace violence. Key changes include a shift from a triennial development of safety plans to an ongoing implementation and review of these plans, ensuring that health care facilities are continually assessing and updating their strategies to protect employees.

Key Provisions

Workplace Violence Prevention Plan

  • Each health care setting is required to develop and implement a workplace violence prevention plan, emphasizing continual protection of employees from violence.
  • Facilities with established safety or workplace violence committees must involve these committees in the development, implementation, and monitoring of the violence prevention plan.

Required Elements of the Plan

  • The workplace violence prevention plan must include comprehensive strategies covering:
    • Security systems, alarms, emergency response, and security personnel.
    • Staffing considerations, including patterns and classifications to reduce time spent alone in high-risk areas.
    • Job design, equipment, and facility layout.
    • First aid and emergency procedures.
    • Reporting mechanisms for violent acts.
    • Employee education, training, and implementation strategies.
    • Assessment of security risks specific to different units and surrounding areas.
    • Processes to assist employees directly affected by violent incidents.

Annual Review and Update

  • Facilities must conduct a comprehensive review and update of their workplace violence prevention plans at least once per year, incorporating emerging issues and findings.

Incident Investigation and Reporting

  • Every health care setting is mandated to conduct timely investigations into all incidents of workplace violence.
  • Investigations must include detailed assessments of the incidents and recommendations to prevent future occurrences.
  • Health care settings are required to submit quarterly reports to relevant committees summarizing incident data, systemic causes, and recommendations for plan modifications. Critical access hospitals must submit reports semi-annually.

summary.text:
Purpose

The main goal of the edits to the proposed legislature bill is to strengthen the measures aimed at preventing workplace violence in healthcare settings. Key changes include the addition of an effective date for the bill and enhanced requirements for conducting investigations and reporting on incidents of workplace violence. Overall, the edits aim to provide clearer guidelines and expectations for health care settings, which are essential for improving safety and protection for employees in potentially hazardous environments.

Key Changes

Amendments to Reporting and Investigation

  • Added a requirement for health care settings to conduct a timely investigation of every workplace violence incident.
  • The bill mandates that findings from investigations, including data and system analyses, must be submitted to the designated committee at least quarterly or biannually, depending on the size and type of facility.
  • Introduced specific categories of health care settings that require different frequencies of reporting based on their classification.

Introduction of Effective Date

  • The edited version includes a new section specifying that the act will take effect on January 1, 2026, making the enforcement timeline explicit.

Additional Clarity and Structure

  • Clarified that reports should comply with federal and state laws concerning the protection of personally identifiable information.
  • Enhanced the language to specify that a summary of findings must be de-identified in compliance with HIPAA regulations.

These changes collectively enhance the structure and accountability mechanisms related to workplace violence in healthcare settings, ensuring better protection for employees and effective responses to incidents.

summary.text:
Purpose

The edits made to the proposed legislature bill aim to enhance the effectiveness and clarity of the workplace violence prevention measures in health care settings. The key content changes include the addition of a new section that sets an effective date for the act and establishes provisions regarding the investigation of violent incidents. The new wording strengthens requirements for health care settings to prevent and respond to workplace violence, ensuring that appropriate protocols are in place for ongoing assessment and improvement.

Key Changes

Introduction of New Sections

  • A new section has been created that specifies the effective date of the bill, which will be January 1, 2026.
  • Another new section specifies that if funding for the act is not provided by June 30, 2025, the act will become null and void.

Investigation Requirements

  • Each health care setting is now required to conduct timely investigations of every incident of workplace violence.
  • The investigations must include assessments of the incident details, response measures, and staffing levels at the time of the incident.

Reporting Guidelines

  • Health care settings must submit a report summarizing investigation findings at least quarterly, with specific rules for critical access and small hospitals where reports must be submitted at least biannually.
  • The submission will include data analysis related to workplace violence, ensuring that personal information is kept confidential as per legal standards.

Annual Review Requirement

  • The language surrounding the annual review of violence incidents and plan adjustments has been clarified, reinforcing that these reviews must inform the ongoing adjustment of preventive measures.

These changes aim to solidify the commitment to improving safety measures for employees in health care settings and ensuring systematic evaluations to prevent workplace violence effectively.
